data.title: Fetching outdated packages and themes failed.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[Description of the issue]

### Steps to Reproduce
Settings > hit Check for updates 


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
I expect to get a list of out of date packages and a prompt to update 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
I get an error that says the following
Fetching outdated packages and themes failed.
when expanded it reads 
(node:12285) DeprecationWarning: os.tmpDir() is deprecated. Use os.tmpdir() instead.

undefined

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%
### Versions
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.4.15
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
OS: Arch Linux. 
Atom was install from the Arch Linux repository

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Uncaught Error: tunneling socket could not be established, cause=connect ETIMEDOUT 147.204.6.136:...
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom**: 1.15.0 ia32
**Electron**: 1.3.13
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 7 Ultimate 
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: tunneling socket could not be established, cause=connect ETIMEDOUT 147.204.6.136:8080

```
At stream.js:74

Error: tunneling socket could not be established, cause=connect ETIMEDOUT 147.204.6.136:8080
    at ClientRequest.onError (/app.asar/node_modules/tunnel-agent/index.js:176:17)
    at ClientRequest.g (events.js:286:16)
    at emitOne (events.js:96:13)
    at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:188:7)
    at Socket.socketErrorListener (_http_client.js:308:9)
    at emitOne (events.js:96:13)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:188:7)
    at emitErrorNT (net.js:1272:8)
    at _combinedTickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:74:11)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:98:9)
```

```

data.title: Bad 'Save As' dialog behaviour in atom version 1.15.0
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Wrong direction in Save As dialog.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run in command line 'atom hello.txt'.
2. Try to 'Save As' (from menu or Ctrl + Shift + S).

**Expected behavior:** In dialog should be path to hello.txt.

**Actual behavior:** I am requested to specify file path manually.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.15.0
OS: Ubuntu 16.04

### Additional Information
I solved it downgrading to atom version 1.14.4.

data.title: update the .zip version
data.body:
The Docs read "The .zip version will not automatically update".How can I update the version to the latest. 
I have clicked the Check for Updates button , but it does not work. The latest version is 1.15.0 ,but it is 1.13.1 ia32 version on my windows. Must I  [down it](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.15.0) ?

data.title: All forward slashes in spec output converted to backslashes
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

A regression from #13825 is causing _all_ forward slashes in spec output to be converted to Windows-style.  For example:
![html-backslash-in-specs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/24280281/ab903138-1025-11e7-9279-43a3c90a3582.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a test that will have forward slashes in its output if it fails
2. Run that spec in the Spec Reporter on Windows and make sure it fails

**Expected behavior:** Forward slashes to remain forward slashes

**Actual behavior:** :scream: Backslashes :scream:

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-fa9092608
Electron: 1.6.4
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'alias' of undefined
data.body:
The error occurs when I am registering a new host in plugin remote-edit2

**Atom**: 1.15.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.13
**OS**: Windows 10
**Thrown From**: [remote-edit2](https://github.com/duxet/remote-edit2) package 3.0.0


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'alias' of undefined

```
At C:\Users\cesar\.atom\packages\remote-edit2\lib\model\host.coffee:34

TypeError: Cannot read property 'alias' of undefined
    at FtpHost.module.exports.Host.getSearchKey (/packages/remote-edit/lib/model/host.coffee:34:63)
    at /packages/remote-edit/lib/model/host.coffee:18:9
    at Config.module.exports.Config.observeKeyPath (/app.asar/src/config.js:616:7)
    at Config.module.exports.Config.observe (/app.asar/src/config.js:141:21)

    at /packages/remote-edit2/lib/model/ftp-host.coffee:32:7)
    at Object.newHostFtp (/packages/remote-edit2/lib/main.coffee:116:16)
    at /packages/remote-edit2/lib/main.coffee:95:73)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:259:29)
    at /app.asar/src/command-registry.js:3:59
    at Object.didConfirmSelection (/app.asar/node_modules/command-palette/lib/command-palette-view.js:106:29)
    at SelectListView.confirmSelection (/app.asar/node_modules/atom-select-list/src/select-list-view.js:301:20)
    at HTMLDivElement.coreConfirm (/app.asar/node_modules/atom-select-list/src/select-list-view.js:67:14)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:259:29)
    at /app.asar/src/command-registry.js:3:59
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:599:16)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:390:22)

data.title: Crash on Win7 within 60 s of startup when a python file is opened
data.body:
### Description

Atom v 1.15.0 crashes on Win7 within 60 s of opening a python file, with and without --safe, with and without --clear-window-state, with and without removing all user settings in `%USERPROFILE%\.atom`. See the listing from the `cmd` session below.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom
2. Open an editor window with a python file (if it isn't open already)
3. Do any action in the editors or menus or just wave the mouse around
4. Atom crashes within a short time, typically < 60 s
[](url)
**Expected behavior:** No crash.

**Actual behavior:** Crash

**Reproduces how often:** 100 % (I have tried more than 20 times and it has crashed every time)

### Versions

```
C:\Users\josteinf>atom --version

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

C:\Users\josteinf>apm --version
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 3.4.4
git 1.9.5.msysgit.0
visual studio 2010
```
### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.


```

data.title: Atom is removing whitespace characters at the ends of lines on its own
data.body:
### Description

Atom removes white space characters from the ends of all lines of the file being edited even from the lines you didn't edit, even it you don't edit the file at all: just load and save it with no changes: your white space characters are gone.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a test file using some other editor and put some lines there which have white space characters a the ends 
2. Open that file in Atom
3. Save it back with no changes
4. Check the test file and see your white space characters at the end of lines are gone

**Expected behavior:** No changes in the lines I didn't edit. No changes in the amount of white space characters unless I ask for that.

**Actual behavior:** The white space characters are removed for the lines I didn't edit, even If I didn't edit a single line in the file and just saved it with no changes whatsoever, all the whitespace characters at the ends of lines are removed.

**Reproduces how often:** Reproduced everytime I tried that.
I tried that on a machine running 1.15.0 editor on a 32-bit Ubuntu 16.04 then checked on MacOS Sierra where 1.13.0 was installed. 1.13.0 worked ok until I agreed to install some update, then it started doing the same

### Versions

1,
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Linux 4.4.0-66-generic i686

2.
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Darwin 16.3.0 x86_64

### Additional Information

Try updating to your Atom through the menu. I don't see this menu on my Atom 1.15.0 running on Ubuntu, and in the 1.13.0 running on MacOS it is the 'Check for Update' menu item in the 'Atom' menu (which actually seems to do nothing as after applying the update and restarting Atom the version remains 1.13.0)

data.title: Updated docs for the node: No such file or directory problem
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change
A more standard solution would be to use the nodejs-legacy package
in ubuntu/debian environments. Updated the linux docs with this information
and the installation instructions for it.

### Alternate Designs

N/A

### Why Should This Be In Core?

N/A

### Benefits

N/A

### Possible Drawbacks

N/A

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: HiDPI Scaling
data.body:
I use Atom (1.15) on two 4K displays (15.6 inch laptop and 27 inch desktop) on Linux (Solus OS). While I have changed the window and font scaling in Gnome tweak tools, Atom does not seems to respect that.

Installing 'hidpi' package scales everything within the window but the menu text is still tiny. 

![screenshot from 2017-03-23 11-21-19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18163728/24229957/cbc71658-0fbf-11e7-9f60-882b690d6d2d.png)

I was wondering if there is anything that can be done about it? Window title text is also too small to read. Perhaps integrating a scaling function for both text as well as window contents would be a good idea given that more and more people have high res screens.

data.title: Opening a New Window Looks Weird
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When opening a New Window, it opens "inside" the old window. It seems to open a tab instead even though it doesn't look like a normal tab - fonts and colors are weird. Dragging the "tab" out of the old window actually restores normal/expected behavior. I've tried running Atom in Safe Mode and using different UI and Syntax theme. Seems to be something wrong with Core and not a theme or package.

### Steps to Reproduce

EDIT: MORE/UPDATED INFO IN [COMMENT](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14045#issuecomment-288519047) BELOW...

Click `File > New Window`

**Expected behavior:**
![screen shot 2017-03-22 at 3 10 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6537823/24216220/cab455b8-0f11-11e7-8b4a-36d9cb4e261f.png)


**Actual behavior:**
![screen shot 2017-03-22 at 3 09 36 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6537823/24216162/949521d8-0f11-11e7-901f-0163036542ab.png)

**Reproduces how often:**
Every time

### Versions
atom --version:
```
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```
apm --version:
```
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.12.0
```
MacOS version:
`10.12.3`

### Additional Information
Config File:
```
"*":
  "atom-beautify":
    css:
      beautify_on_save: true
      configPath: "~/.csscomb.json"
      default_beautifier: "CSScomb"
    general:
      _analyticsUserId: "d27ee7d6-68e7-428b-8914-7471776d7198"
    html:
      beautify_on_save: true
      default_beautifier: "Pretty Diff"
      indent_size: 2
      wrap_line_length: 0
    markdown:
      beautify_on_save: true
    sass:
      beautify_on_save: true
    scss:
      beautify_on_save: true
      configPath: "~/.csscomb.json"
      default_beautifier: "CSScomb"
      indent_size: 2
    twig:
      beautify_on_save: true
      indent_size: 2
      wrap_line_length: 0
  autoprefixer:
    runOnSave: true
  "color-picker":
    preferredFormat: "HEX"
    uppercaseColorValues: true
  core:
    automaticallyUpdate: false
    closeDeletedFileTabs: true
    customFileTypes:
      "text.html.twig": [
        "html"
      ]
    openEmptyEditorOnStart: false
    projectHome: "/Users/jalenconner/Projects"
    telemetryConsent: "limited"
    themes: [
      "nucleus-dark-ui"
      "duotone-dark-sea-syntax"
    ]
    useCustomTitleBar: true
  "double-tag": {}
  editor:
    autoIndentOnPaste: false
    fontFamily: "Hasklig"
    invisibles:
      eol: " "
    scrollPastEnd: true
    showInvisibles: true
    softWrap: true
    tabType: "soft"
  emmet: {}
  "exception-reporting":
    userId: "971b39b3-f542-abab-e5b7-1a51b6eab907"
  "file-icons": {}
  "genesis-ui":
    distractionFree: {}
  "gist-it":
    newGistsDefaultToPrivate: true
    userToken: "2da3c7eccc51f0a494ad19f688fdcc4407050cdd"
  "git-diff":
    showIconsInEditorGutter: true
  "grammar-selector": {}
  "highlight-selected":
    hideHighlightOnSelectedWord: true
    ignoreCase: true
  "isotope-ui":
    backgroundGradient: true
    fontFamily: "Source Sans Pro"
    lowContrastTooltip: true
    minimalMode: true
  "less-than-slash": {}

data.title: Inconsistent syntax highlighting of transition properties
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Using different keywords as `transition-property` results in different syntax highlighting.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use the syntax theme 'One Light'.
2. Create a CSS file.
3. Add the following Code:
```
div {
  transition-property: width;
}

div {
  transition-property: color;
}

div {
  transition-property: background;
}
```
**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The keywords `width`, `color` and `background` should have the same syntax highlighting.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

![bildschirmfoto 2017-03-22 um 10 54 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419747/24192104/328b0250-0eee-11e7-87fc-ab910d26446b.png)

![bildschirmfoto 2017-03-22 um 10 55 19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419747/24192105/33db41c4-0eee-11e7-9088-693e69534d91.png)

![bildschirmfoto 2017-03-22 um 10 55 36](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419747/24192118/3bfe44b4-0eee-11e7-912b-afe3a6ef99c3.png)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1

### Additional Information

[MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties) lists `background` as an animated property, it also works in all browsers I have tested so far. Therefore I think it should not be highlighted as invalid. At least `width` and `color` I would suspect to have the same syntax highlighting.

data.title: Text in file renaming dialog won't fit
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I right-click on the file tree and rename a file that has a long path, the path won't fit in the dialog. Instead of growing horizontally (I have about 2000px that it could use), it shows a hard-to-see vertical scrollbar.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. right click on a file in the tree view that has a long name or path
2. in the context menu, pick "Rename"

**Expected behavior:**
I would like the dialog to grow horizontally so that it could show the whole path

**Actual behavior:**
The dialog width stays the same, dialog grows vertically and a scrollbar appears

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0


### Additional Information.

data.title: Add "Copy Path" to file name tab contextual menu
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The options in the contextual menu when control- or right-clicking on a file name tab do not include the ability to copy the file path. The use case for this is when I have a spec file open and I want to paste its path in Terminal. The only workaround is to show the item in the Finder and drag the file into Terminal to get its path.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file
2. Control- or right-click on the file name in the tab bar
3. View options

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I expect there to be a "Copy path" under "Show in Finder"

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

No such option exists.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0```

### Steps to Reproduce

I use widnows 10
and set environment variables "ComSpec" change cmd.exe to powershell

atom need update cmd script to support powershell

thank you.


### Versions
ATOM Versions: 1.15.0 x64
OS:windows 10 1607

data.title: Optimize style sheets loading
data.body:
This pull request takes advantage of snapshots auxiliary data to minimize the I/O associated to reading a core package's style sheets when opening Atom. Specifically, we will now store all the sources, digests and style sheet paths in the snapshot blob, so that we can load them all at once during startup and avoid accessing the file system at runtime.

The following is a CPU profile taken on master after merging #14024:

![screen shot 2017-03-21 at 09 52 17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24139415/49bfb1aa-0e1c-11e7-9ffc-08659daced45.png)

If we zoom in the various sections of this profile, we can see that `LessCache` shows up quite frequently:

![screen shot 2017-03-21 at 09 52 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24139443/6028c12a-0e1c-11e7-9910-2278bb4506dd.png)

![screen shot 2017-03-21 at 09 53 16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24139445/60528bc2-0e1c-11e7-9a15-f84a4bd50af3.png)

![screen shot 2017-03-21 at 09 53 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24139448/605d2f78-0e1c-11e7-8bd0-a45b2422d091.png)

After these changes, this is how the same profile looks like:

![screen shot 2017-03-21 at 09 56 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24139523/ab84caba-0e1c-11e7-96e8-9b1dc0f04dee.png)

You can notice how Atom now loads `~ 100ms` faster thanks to the minimization of the I/O associated with listing and reading less style sheets; this improvement should also make startup time more consistent across reloads because it will make Atom rely less on the file system.

One thing to note is that we will still need to update `LessCache` and, as a result, write and read from `~/.atom/compile-cache/less` when booting up Atom. We could potentially minimize that cost too by batching reads and writes, but we think we could defer this to later and address other concerns (like packages preloading) first.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: How to disable "Please restart Atom to apply the changes"
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Description

After last update of atom and all packages the message "Please restart Atom to apply the changes" started coming up after each restart.

OS: OSX 10.12.3

data.title: Deprecated calls - Atom core : Autocomplete provider
data.body:
### Description

[Description of the issue]

I use https://atom.io/packages/api-workbench and I often see this message

![bugatom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9306961/24093275/55667ea4-0d53-11e7-9c39-3c7bd4ac6ffd.png)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I expect this issue to be solved by update but it is not the case.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Not solved:

```
atom core (1 deprecation)
Autocomplete provider 'Object(undefined)' returns suggestions with a prefix attribute. 
The prefix attribute is now replacementPrefix and is optional. 
See https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/wiki/Provider-API
AutocompleteManager.deprecateForSuggestion - C:\Users\Jacques\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.15.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\autocomplete-plus\lib\autocomplete-manager.js:484:14
<unknown> - C:\Users\Jacques\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.15.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\autocomplete-plus\lib\autocomplete-manager.js:341:38
```

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Each time that Atom seems to check for update

### Versions
Atom : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome : 52.
OS : Windows 10 64 bit Education

### Additional Information

Not

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Invalid Point: (NaN, 0)

[Enter steps to reproduce:]

**Atom**: 1.15.0 x64

data.title: Atom crashes on launch and/or when opening files
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom, running on Windows 10, crashes on launch revealing an error message popup:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9751401/24083518/a2bec058-0cae-11e7-9b8f-626fb2565fb3.png)

This happens for command line launches, launches from the Atom icon on the start menu, and from the command line in safe mode. Additionally, if I select reload and the program comes up (it usually does when I select the reload option from the pop-up) then it fails to open files, see this GIF (pop image to a new tab to see full-sized):

![animated_fail](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9751401/24083535/f3f08862-0cae-11e7-8d1f-832ba2a99be8.gif)

However, if I change to a new folder at this point Atom, and try to open various files, sometimes a file will open **and at this point Atom's file open behavior will return to normal**, at least until I kill it and restart. Sometimes changing to a different directory makes Atom briefly start normally, but this behavior stops over time; I cannot determine a rule for why some directories work/files open and other do not.

### Steps to Reproduce

I do not expect this to reproduce as it is currently only happening on one of my windows systems, and not on the other. This started with my previously installed Atom, which was working as of about a month or so ago, and failed upon my running it today (this follows the update to 1.15). However, I did a clean install and deleted ~/.atom, so:

1. Do a clean install of Atom, including deleting `~/.atom`
2. Launch Atom
3. That would be it, except you're probably launched!

**Expected behavior:** Expect Atom to open normally without error pop-up and to open files normally.

**Actual behavior:** Error pop-up occurs on launch or on opening files.

**Reproduces how often:** Error message appears almost all of the time, except as noted above.

### Versions

atom --version
>Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm --version
>apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.11.0.windows.3
visual studio

OS/System Info:
>OS Name:                   Microsoft Windows 10 Home
OS Version:                10.0.14393 N/A Build 14393
OS Manufacturer:           Microsoft Corporation
System Manufacturer:       HP
System Model:              750-150
System Type:               x64-based PC

### Additional Information

This is happening on a Windows 10 (home) PC. I have access to a Windows 10 (pro) tablet and the problem does not occur there, at least not so far. **UPDATE: this other computer is running Atom 1.14, not 1.15.** I cannot afford to break this one so I cannot check if this is the cause!

I am willing to help diagnose, but I am not an Atom expert or developer so please spell out what you want me to do. 😄

data.title: can't type numbers in html files
data.body: Hi, i have clean install latest atom on Ubuntu 14.04 64b. When i just save any file as .html file, i can't type numbers in that file anymore. All simbols like $#% works, but no numbers (from enhanced side keyboard also).

data.title: freezing
data.body: atom freeze after start and i tried atom --safe and still the same

data.title: 'Toggle Find in Buffer' or 'Find in buffer' makes vertical scrollbar disappear
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

'Toggle Find in Buffer' or 'Find in buffer' makes vertical scrollbar disappear

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run atom or atom --safe
2. Open some text files. I open 3, the third is long enough to require a scrollbar.
3. Do 'Find'->'Find in Buffer' or 'Find'->'Toggle Find in Buffer' while on the third file mentioned in 2 above.

**Expected behavior:**

Scrollbar stays visible and usable.

**Actual behavior:**

Scrollbar disappears.

**Reproduces how often:**

Reproducible 90 to 100%

### Versions

```
[philwyett@rebellion antergos_packages]$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.4.15
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
[philwyett@rebellion antergos_packages]$ apm --version
(node:22439) DeprecationWarning: os.tmpDir() is deprecated. Use os.tmpdir() instead.
apm  1.17.0
npm  4.4.1
node 7.7.3 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.12.0
[philwyett@rebellion antergos_packages]$
```

### Additional Information

OS: Antergos (arch based)

Screenshot in normal mode:

![screenshot from 2017-03-18 03-06-16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24805379/24068544/86aae070-0b89-11e7-8128-26d8f6e818e5.png)

Screenshot in safe mode:

![screenshot from 2017-03-18 03-09-02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24805379/24068548/95a50b00-0b89-11e7-8a7b-a56cbfd3c1ac.png)

As can be seen, no vertical scrollbar.

Attached is the text file used in screenshots.

[iso_build_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/852120/iso_build_log.txt)
